catalogue_raissonne: Bartsch 47; Hollstein 68 i; Dutuit 47 i/iii, Rovinski 103 i/iii
creditline: Gift of Elizabeth, Julie, and Catherine Andrus in memory of John and Marion Andrus
description: profile bust of a male figure facing R with tall hat, long white beard, and coat
markings: on verso: penned in brown ink, bottom center: Pierre Mariette, Lugt 1790, followed by \"1672\"; black stamp, LL: Ernst Theodor Rodenacker, Lugt 2438; two brown stamps, LL, Berlin Print Room, Lugt 1608 and 234, with \"[a.?d.?] 1886\" in date field; brown stamp, left edge, Paul Davidsohn, Lugt 654; two undefined collector\'s marks, LR
provenance: Pierre Mariette II  (1634-1716), Lugt 1790 (1672), Paris. Ernst Theodor Rodenacker (about 1840-before 1894), Lugt 2438, Dantzig. Berlin Print Room, deaccessioned as duplicate, Lugt 1608 and 234, 1886('). Paul Davidsohn (1839-1927'), Lugt 654, born Danzig. [C. & J. Goodfriend, New York; sold March 5, 1985, to Andrus]; John E. Andrus III, Wayzata, Minn.; by descent to his daughters, Elizabeth, Katie, and Julie; gave to MIA, 2015. Earlier provenances have been gathered, but further research will increase our knowledge of their histories.
text: By the 1620s, the Dutch sought out tronies (head studies) as unvarnished glimpses into the human spirit. This rare early state shows Jan Lievens’ economical use of stippling and wiry lines to capture this (probably) live model, achieving the feel of a drawing. Like his friend Rembrandt, Lievens was born in Leiden, Holland, and was drawn to wizened faces.
title: Bust of an Old Man with a High Cap
